item.title: Blizzard agrees to redesign Overwatch hero's appearance after backlash
item.content:encoded:
Diego Argüello, Contributing Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

February 11, 2026

3 Min Read

Overwatch game director Aaron Keller has released a statement regarding Anran, one of the latest characters introduced in the online shooter, in response to backlash from both the fanbase and the character's own voice actor regarding her design.

Anran was officially added to the roster on Tuesday, February 10, with the launch of Season 1: Conquest, as Overwatch officially ditched the "2" on its title and underwent a soft reboot. Players expressed excitement over the character based on concept art, a promotional comic, and an animated short shared by developer Blizzard, the latter of which was released in August of last year. The response regarding the in-game design, however, wasn't as positive.

The criticisms around Anran, a character of Chinese nationality, revolved around what fans call the "same face syndrome," pointing out that character design in Overwatch, especially for East Asian women characters, has gotten homogeneous.

Related:Cairn's prickly protagonist serves a powerful purpose - Narrative Notebook #1

As Kotaku reported last week, Anran's final design ended up being fairly similar to characters Kiriko and Juno, discarding the sharper facial features and longer nose seen on promotional videos. The final result included a much rounder face, with a shrunken-down nose in a similar fashion to Kiriko and Juno.

Via her personal TikTok account, Fareeha Andersen, the voice actor behind Anran, expressed her disappointment over the character's design differences. "I got to mourn Anran between the design I had hoped for her and the design we ended up with," Andersen says in the video. "Because I think in her comic and the cinematic Elemental Kin, there was a precedent set by it. There was an unspoken promise that said, 'We are going to challenge the beauty standards plaguing, ransacking media these days,' right? The Ozempic-chic, the 'contour your nose, you have no nose, the tiniest nose,' and I think because of that precedence, people feel understandably let down."

Andersen added that she shared the community's concerns with the Blizzard team, and encouraged others to do so as well with "boldness and kindness."

Yesterday, Overwatch's game director released a video update on social media addressing the concerns. "The team is currently discussing what it'd take to make Anran look and feel more like the fierce older sister that we all envisioned her to be," Keller said. "We're so proud of the work that our team has put into Anran and the rest of the five heroes launching in season 1, and we agree that she can be even better if we get this aspect of her right in game."

Related:Book Excerpt: Designing the User Experience of Game Development Tools

The director added that the team is hoping to make an update to her design at some point during season 1. "Our hero models are incredibly complicated, and we really need to test out what we can do."

In other Overwatch-related news, developers at the studio formed a nearly 200-person union at Blizzard in May of last year. Meanwhile, Redhill Games, which was co-dev of Overwatch 2 at the time, made an undisclosed number of job cuts in November following the announcement of a restructuring program.
